title: Gateway        (Heechee Saga, #1)
author: Pohl, Frederik
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Gateway is what I would consider to be a true science fiction novel. Everything about this book comes across as serious commentary that can be tossed Gateway is what I would consider to be a true science fiction novel. Everything about this book comes across as serious commentary that can be tossed around in the reader’s head for possible relevance in the present world, as well as contemplations of Fredrik Pohl’s world 40-plus years ago.The tone of the book is reminiscent of H.P. Lovecraft (Mountains of Madness) or Stanislaw Lem (Solaris). It’s narrated in the first person by the main character, Robinette Broadhead. As such, everything that comes off the page is filtered through his pragmatic views. There is very little heroism and an abundance of humanism.Gateway is filled with relevant themes that have survived and even intensified over the forty years since its publication. At the top of the list is a picture of space exploration that has been handed over to the private sector. At the time of the book’s publication, mankind had already taken its “giant leap” and the buzz concerning the forthcoming Space Shuttle program was how to make space profitable. Gateway offers such a vision and we’ve taken more than a few steps towards its fulfillment in the present.Other themes that still resonate include our irrepressible drive to destroy the environment and how that destruction will affect food supplies. Gateway also comments on the continued march towards the disintegration of all social support for society. Healthcare is purely a function of wealth and life expectancy falls along the same divide. And immigration is touched upon in terms of the force-of-character that is required to give up everything on a belief that life could be better in a completely foreign place.Gateway is a classic among a mountain of available sci-fi pulp. Of all first-in-series sci-fi books that I have read, only the sequels to Gateway have my serious attention and my commitment to continue living in Frederik Pohl’s world....more

title: Ender’s Game        (Ender's Saga, #1)
author: Card, Orson Scott
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can see why Ender’s Game would be a favorite for a movie adaptation. Most of the story centers around the game that Ender plays for the development I can see why Ender’s Game would be a favorite for a movie adaptation. Most of the story centers around the game that Ender plays for the development of his command capabilities. His ultimate goal is to win absolute victory in the ongoing war with the “buggers,” a dehumanized enemy of humanity (think Starship Troopers). To this extent, the game is repeated multiple times throughout the initial two-thirds of the book. Therefore, making a movie (and a better book) would involve cutting some significant portion of this repetitive part of the story.The plot is carried out by characters who are pre-adolescent children, which creates a confusing contradiction throughout the book. Card uses his power of narration to repeatedly assert their young age, but then writes their thoughts, feelings, and experiences from an adult perspective. In this way, Card criss-crosses two, mostly exclusive worlds back and forth throughout the book and hinders a full immersion into the story.The positive aspects of the book bring light to some of humanity’s fundamental instincts for war and violence against our enemies and perceived enemies. This aspect of the book allows the reader to question such instincts in the light of our present society and human abilities. Another positive is that Ender grows in his understanding of his purpose and the requirements of his destiny along the way. And the growth of a character is always an insightful reading experience....more

review: Prior to this book, my experience with Arthur C. Clarke was limited to viewing the movie, 2001, A Space Odyssey. My thoughts on that movie were that tPrior to this book, my experience with Arthur C. Clarke was limited to viewing the movie, 2001, A Space Odyssey. My thoughts on that movie were that the first two hours were amazing. The movie depicted humanity reaching out into space and HAL, depicted at a time when computers were little more than glorified calculators, brought about provocative thoughts about computers advancing to the point where a sole could be created from code. Then the final scenes of the movie just happened: flashing lights, a space baby, and an old man in a white room. To put it bluntly, it didn’t work for me.Hence we have Childhood’s End with a story arc that closely follows A Space Odyssey. Clarke puts forth a realistic extrapolation of societal evolution that is drastically altered by a visiting race of benevolent but omnipotent aliens. He contemplates a human society that is freed from the troubles of poverty and war. A society that is blessed with an abundance of time which is used to further our knowledge of things that are of a deep personal interest to ourselves. But little-by-little the plot advances towards an end that is rooted in the paranormal. The outcome of humanity’s fate is hinted at, but only Clarke, as the writer, knows what he is writing about. To put it bluntly, it didn’t work for me....more

title: London
author: Rutherfurd, Edward*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With over eleven hundred pages, I was anticipating London to be both entertaining and educational. I was hoping for that magical merging of history anWith over eleven hundred pages, I was anticipating London to be both entertaining and educational. I was hoping for that magical merging of history and fiction, which gives life to history and historical significance to life. Rutherfurd's book, however, misses this anticipation by a wide margin.London covers almost two thousand years of history and focuses on a few familial hereditary lines throughout that span of time. Each period of history that is selected by Rutherfurd is complemented by stories that focus on these families. But the stories are mostly rooted in domestic issues. Domestic problems such as infidelity, disobedient spouses, and marriage arrangements dominate every time period covered by Rutherfurd. The history is often provided in narrative form along side the domestic tales and, as a result, life and history move forward on parallel paths. These two vital components seldom merged into that powerful combination known as great historical fiction.I'll also add that Rutherford stories tend to be prosaic. While he touches on the harsh conditions that humans have endured throughout history, his characters rarely express their suffering that accompanied these hardships. While narratives and positive happenstances occupy spans of pages, descriptions of the tragic or horrific are limited to brief sentences. While this approach makes for a pleasant reading experience, it does not give justice to the realities of our existence....more

title: The Painter
author: Heller, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Painter focuses on the squishy-spongy relationships that we all have with moral absolutes. While I believe that moral absolutes exist, life is tooThe Painter focuses on the squishy-spongy relationships that we all have with moral absolutes. While I believe that moral absolutes exist, life is too complex to allow most people to ever grow close to them except through extreme efforts that seem less than human. For most people, compromises, sacrifices, and rationalizations keep us tossing in the waves of reality and leaving us with at least one riddle: Is a good person that does evil things for good reasons still a good person? That is what this book is about.But it’s also be about loss. About how someone can be such a part of you that if they die, especially suddenly, you become something other than who you were; something less than who you were. And being less human can only lead to cruelty, to a darkening of sorts, to acts that reflect this loss of self. And this diminished state lives in our creations.In between the good and evil and loss, there is a pure peace associated with this book. The setting allows for the moral complexities to be focused. This book abounds with imagery of mountains at sunset, the pure joy of rain hitting the desert floor, laminar streams filled with trout, and tree-filled forests. These passages allow the reader to absorb the weight of the plot and refresh the mind for the dilemmas to come. And the painter paints. His thoughts are transferred to the canvas as abstract bits of objects, motion, and color. Reading about this process offers a creative way for both the main character and the reader to decompress between the more suspenseful moments.And if there is a problem with this book, it seems overshadowed by all that I just described. While Heller writes in a style that is unique and refreshing, his plot has a propensity for hitting all of the remote possibilities. His characters make all the long-shots and they never seem to miss out on random meetings with their fellow characters. Even nature is inclined to act in their favor at times. While this aspect of the book is completely unbelievable, the ends justify the means. In life, the ends always do even if logic requires us to pay deference to more important things....more

review: As a primer for a forthcoming trip to London, London Stories: London Walks served its purpose well. The book is comprised of several chapters each of As a primer for a forthcoming trip to London, London Stories: London Walks served its purpose well. The book is comprised of several chapters each of which focuses on a different London topic, and each chapter is written by a tour guide that specializes in that topic. The walled City of London, the original land that was once occupied by the Romans, then abandoned during the more peaceful dark ages, and then repopulated for protection from Viking raids, is one such chapter. Other chapters cover Saint James, Greenwich, Soho Village, and Westminster.The end result is that I now have a nicely filled Google Map of way-points, each of which has some bit of information attached to it. The intent is to have interesting places near at hand and to know what those places are about. We will now be able to divert to the location of a remaining segment of an original Roman road or to the still-existing location where one of Jack the Ripper's victims was found. If we happen to be considering a break at a pub, then we can now make it one of the oldest pubs in London, or the pub where Marks discussed his ideas with fellow patrons, or a quiet place with fantastic views of the city. The book is written with the enthusiasm of those that want to share the history of a place that has been populated centuries. The passion of the writers shines through every chapter and the effect is a reading experience that is richer than a voluminous, matter-of-fact guide book....more

review: The Art Forger starts out strong. Shapiro uses her main character to describe the effect that a powerful work of art has upon her while in her presencThe Art Forger starts out strong. Shapiro uses her main character to describe the effect that a powerful work of art has upon her while in her presence. The feelings conveyed by Shapiro are not unlike my own experience when I found myself in front of Manet’s A Bar at the Folies-Bergère while in London a couple of years ago: It’s such a magnificent being. So alive, yet more like the sensation of life, rather than how life actually is. Color and emotion pulse from the canvas. Finding this type empathy in a book is a moving experience.After the intense beginning, the story transitions into a mystery novel, which is a genre that I usually find frustrating to read. This frustrations stem from the type of suspense that is manufactured by the writer and usually conveyed through the willful non-disclosure of events that are fully know to the writer. If this were all there was to The Art Forger, a mystery born out of manufactured suspense, it would have been a disappointing book after such a moving start.The Art Forger takes a unique path to presenting its mystery. Shapiro essentially provides herself with two overlapping sources of plausible deniability for manufactured suspense. First, the plot is presented in the first person, which places the conclusion and understanding of the personal narrative naturally at the end of the story. And second, the key event that is withheld happened a century before the events of the personal narrative. Time itself covers the event and leads to questions can never be answered, even by the writer. This combination of mystery born out of an understanding of human decisions and the fog of time made The Art Forger a mystery worth reading.And did I mention that art permeates this book? It’s an added bonus for anyone who sees art as a reflection of ourselves and the world we live in....more

title: The Dog Stars
author: Heller, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel is very much a violent adventure novel. The world is nine years into the aftermath of a virus that suddenly and almost completely kills offThis novel is very much a violent adventure novel. The world is nine years into the aftermath of a virus that suddenly and almost completely kills off humanity. Those that survived now try to kill each other off, as if our natural state of survival depends on killing every other survivor that you come across. This aspect of the novel is a bit hard to believe given the vast amount of resources that would have been left behind for the survivors under such a scenario. Even guns, in America, are depicted as being in short supply, but it’s Heller’s world. It’s Heller’s ability to write, to tell his story, that makes this novel special. His prose exhibit the sparseness of Ernest Hemingway. He promotes intimacy with his reader through an abandonment of punctuation, which is similar to the style of Cormac McCarthy. Heller, however, takes this style one step further and occasionally digresses into what I would describe as being poetic. The result is a style that peaks at critical moments with short, incomplete sentences which communicate impact. It worked. It got under my skin and I could feel the action.There‘s also a philosophical side to this novel where Heller explores today’s political divide between people. His post apocalyptic world allows him to remove all the people and in doing so, he removes the countless nuanced opinions on political philosophy. He then searches out the a fundamental source for our present-day strife under his petri dish conditions. The result boils down to a choice between self-sufficiency and community. Heller explores this choice throughout the novel and delivers his opinion as the book progresses.My feelings of discontent with The Dog Stars primarily reside with its ending, which boldly and abruptly broadcasts "sequel." Stories that end this way sacrifice their completeness for something that looks and feels a lot like marketing, and marketing is not literature. Additionally, Heller’s love of all things Colorado becomes very apparent with his prolonged and repeated descriptions of the mountains and his love for fishing. Initially, these scenes fill in the backstory of his main character, but they soon become tedious and irrelevant to the plot.In short, The Dog Stars provides great action and great writing, even with its naturalistic indulgences. However, don’t look to closely into Heller’s post-apocalyptic world, and keep an eye out for the forthcoming sequel, which he now owes to his readers....more

review: And the Tide Turns is a specialized work of time travel science fiction that would appeal to a certain type of audience. This audience would primarilyAnd the Tide Turns is a specialized work of time travel science fiction that would appeal to a certain type of audience. This audience would primarily consist of those who enjoy stories saturated in testosterone. To that end, the novel is filled with action sequences, shootouts, military-esque black operatives, and self-centered men who engage in pissing contests at every opportunity. All this hyper-action inevitably leads to scenes filled with eye-rolling implausibility, even when considered within the book's macho-man context.The time travel elements somewhat elevate this novel above its testosterone overdose. Dalton gives reason to think through the plot and to contemplate the physical possibilities of time travel. Ideas associated with encountering other versions of yourself are put forward. Additionally, if the past were changed, those in the future would also change, without ever noticing it. Their physical selves would instantly adjust to their rewritten history. But Dalton’s time travel writing also falters at times. Characters from various points in time are poorly defined as to their purpose or effect, and Dalton’s stated rules are ignored when it's convenient not to have rules.The testosterone in this book, however, is forever present. Whether intentional or unintentional, Dalton creates an environment that excludes women from any meaningful part in the story. When women do appear in the story, they are portrayed as incompetent, grotesque, or helpless. Even if the benefit of the doubt were given to Dalton regarding his intent, his work could only improve by learning to write competently about this particular half of the human race....more

title: In Love
author: Hayes, Alfred
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Happiness, anger, pain and pleasure are succinct feelings. They are felt at times appropriate to the event that prompts them. And while we may feel thHappiness, anger, pain and pleasure are succinct feelings. They are felt at times appropriate to the event that prompts them. And while we may feel these emotions in various degrees, each of us understands them in a singular way. Love, however, takes each of these feelings as well as others and applies them all in various amounts to different situations. The result is that love never feels the same way twice and for that reason, love is confusing, irrational, and possibly impossible to communicate in a meaningful way to another person; even to the one you love. It is this impossibility that Alfred Hayes takes on as a challenge in In Love and he succeeds in a very unique way.Hayes captures every instance of his narrator experience of love at the moment it occurs. As a result, we are continuously aware of his thoughts and feelings as complex as they are. Each thought and emotion is addressed as it's experienced, no matter how contrary to the preceding moment or to the next.And while this may sound confusing, it comes across as making sense because we've all been through the same human experience at some point in our lives. We've all done stupid things while in love, even while knowing that they were stupid, simply because of the hope that those stupid things created. We've all, in the moment, thought about and felt each possibility as it relates to someone else; each thought and feeling separated by a comma (and each sub-thought and sub-feeling included in a set of parentheses). Yes, it may sound confusing, but because we know what this is, and because Hayes captures this so beautifully, In Love comes across as genuine, and his book is well worth the experience....more

review: This was a follow-up book after reading Cuba Libre by Elmore Leonard. Leonard's ability to use human complexity to produce a mystery created a desire This was a follow-up book after reading Cuba Libre by Elmore Leonard. Leonard's ability to use human complexity to produce a mystery created a desire to read a traditional mystery novel by an equally prolific writer. It took two seconds to decide upon Agatha Christie.In contrast Leonard's style, Christy forcefully moves her characters through her plot. It's fairly obvious that the plot was methodically planned by Christie prior to writing the book. The characters act in synchronicity with the plot and they serve its twists and turns on cue. They voyage, die, love, and commit crimes just when needed in order to keep the story moving forward towards its anticipated ending. While the same sort of planning may be true of Leonard, he always seems to hold open the possibility that his characters could act differently should their spirit move them to do so, changing their acts in a moment’s notice, and changing the course of the book. Christie is why I usually shun mysteries and Leonard makes mysteries worthwhile.The book itself is a typical mystery novel. While the journey from beginning to end can be fun (as was once depicted in one memorable episode of M*A*S*H) I always feel cheated by these types of novels. Of course the villain did the deed, but the mystery is a product of the plot rather than an outcome of unpredictable human nature. The characters are developed just enough to fit into the plot and their interactions seem silly because they have no human foundation. Overall, this is not a bad book but this is not how life happens....more

The book’s own contemporaneous explanation of publishing at the time describes the benefits of producing a lengthy novel. It’s interesting to note that these benefits were only of value to the writers and the publishers of the time and not the readers. Even with all of its wordiness, the main focus of the book is still remarkable for someone like me that loves books. I’ve often think about writers like Jack London, who wrote mostly for money and only occasionally, almost by accident, hit upon a truly good piece of literature. And then there is Hemingway who produced a fraction of London’s work mostly because he constantly strove “to make something really true and sometimes truer than true.” New Grub Street dives into writers like these, explores the consequences of their craft, and places them into perspective against London society in the later part of the Victorian era....more

title: A Critical Analysis of Patriotism as an Ethical Concept
author: Reidenbach, Clarence
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: We all know what patriotism is. It's a concept that occupies our lives anytime our minds contemplate our country. And if you consider its overarching We all know what patriotism is. It's a concept that occupies our lives anytime our minds contemplate our country. And if you consider its overarching ability to co-opt religions, political parties, and regional beliefs, patriotism may indeed be the ultimate religion that controls our collective future. Patriotism may be responsible for more destruction in the world than any other concept that permeates humanity. And yet it seemingly takes us down those destructive paths effortlessly. Patriotism stirs our fears, calls us to love, directs us to hate, inflates our pride, bands us together, and shapes a version of reality that is unified even if untrue. Patriotism may indeed be the ultimate form of tyranny and yet we often give ourselves over to this tyranny time and time again.A Critical Analysis breaks the concept of patriotism apart, contemplates its origins, and explains why patriotism exists. Reidenbach's treatment of the subject is extensive spanning the spectrum of humanity’s evolution and even reaching back to our origins as a part of a stronger multi-celled variety of microbial life. As a defining document for what patriotism is, this book stands on its own and it has not diminished during its 100 years of existence.Even in the area where A Critical Analysis is dated, where it considers a world that was engulfed in the throes of World War I, there is modern value to Reidenbach observations. At the time this book was written, the world was fractured and isolated while the world of today is exceedingly more accessible. The value of Reidenbach's static view lies in the path that it illuminates, stretching between then and now.Beginning with airline travel and blossoming with the rise of the internet, social relationships are continuing to branch out to all parts of the world. Certain realizations about the people of other countries make it ever more difficult to reasonably elevate one's own country above another. The result of this progress has served to diminish unfounded fear, hate, and pride, which are ingredients of patriotic fervor.Lastly, I would venture to say that most modern books on the subject of patriotism are likely mired in subtle or overt secondary messages. If one has a particular flavor of patriotism in mind there is a writer that will fulfill their imaginations. In stark contrast to these modern books, A Critical Analysis was written as an objective philosophical study on the subject of patriotism, with the possible exception of the final chapter. In those final paragraphs, Reidenbach implies his desire for world peace in a world where patriotism is, and always will be, a reality of life.An electronic copy of this book can be downloaded from the following web address. It should be noted that the OCR version of this book has a few digital remnants that have not been edited out and it also contains a few formatting glitches. However, these issues only create an occasional distraction from the content. https://archive.org/details/criticala......more

title: The Destroyers
author: Garrett, Randall
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I would characterize this short story as soft science fiction. In fact, I was probably a third of the way through the story until I realized that the I would characterize this short story as soft science fiction. In fact, I was probably a third of the way through the story until I realized that the story was taking place on another planet and that the characters were other-than-human. Nevertheless, the deception had a purpose in that it allowed the story to slip into its central theme without the distraction of having to understand and visualize an alien setting.The story was first published over fifty years ago but the central theme stretches forwards and backwards from that point in time rather effortlessly. This is probably due to the fact that humans, and apparently non-humans, have a tendency to assert their own personal perceptions of their own perfect societies on other societies that they see as backwards. And if that assertion requires the destruction of the other societies, then that’s just a part of the adage: sometimes to create you must first destroy.The story does a good job in providing the perspective of those being conquered. Given that the United States has primarily been involved with doing the conquering here on this planet, this different point of view could be considered enlightening (or it could simply be dismissed, in which case you would probably not like this story). The story also emphasizes the fact that a society that appears to be backwards is probably just different. After all, for a society to be a society in the first place there must be elements of that society that to our surprise, and possible dismay, actually work....more

review: I find it difficult to relate Elmore Leonard stories to larger universal themes mostly because I'm too damn interested in the story. His characters arI find it difficult to relate Elmore Leonard stories to larger universal themes mostly because I'm too damn interested in the story. His characters are constantly entertaining and his plots always have a sense of randomness to them.Tishomingo Blues holds true with this perception with its mixture of backwoods mafia, big city drug dealers, and characters that take risks under the guise of desire. The story is pure entertainment due things that are familiar as well as things that are unfamiliar. And if you think this story is not for you, then your path through its pages will not be unlike that of its main character, Dennis Lenahan.As for larger universal themes, well, we all have things we like to do. Some may call them hobbies, onlookers may call them obsessions, but while engaged with these most favorite of activities, we are also vulnerable to others. Those that wish to lead us into certain situations would be wise to know our passions and to act 'serious' right along with us. After all, a wolf in sheep's clothing is bound have a successful hunt....more

title: HMS Ulysses
author: MacLean, Alistair
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It’s revealing when a  starts out with a reference to a different book. In fact, The Cruel Sea by Nicholas Monsarrat remains my favorite novel aIt’s revealing when a  starts out with a reference to a different book. In fact, The Cruel Sea by Nicholas Monsarrat remains my favorite novel about life in the Royal Navy during the years that comprised World War II. HMS Ulysses has many of the same elements as Monsarrat’s novel, but Monsarrat practices control over his writing, he knows that magical point where language needs to stop so that the reader’s imagination can complete the imagery and feelings being conveyed. In Ulysses, Alistair MacLean tends to monopolize the reader’s mind. It’s certainly not intolerable, but he does over-describe things to the point where it feels like one’s imagination has been pushed aside.The action in Ulysses is a bit over the top; as if MacLean is trying to compress the entire variety of wartime experiences into the single mission being chronicled. At times, the action is gripping, but in total it becomes overwhelming to the point of disbelief. For those that enjoy Westerns that feature forever-loaded revolvers and heros that escape death time after time, this story of survival is the naval equivalent of that genre. As war stories often go, the characters tend to be instruments of the plot. Bad things happen to them, but the feelings of the victims cannot be fully realized because much of their background is missing. To make matters worse, the characters are referred to at different times by one of their many monikers. Their rank, position, the acronym of their position, their last name, nickname, and first name are all used interchangeably, which creates confusion and further distances the reader from the characters.Overall, HMS Ulysses is not a bad naval war novel. As a first novel, MacLean makes an honest attempt to convey and expand upon his own first-hand experiences aboard the HMS Royalist during WWII. The sincerity comes through and I felt that he was reaching for something greater than his story. The problem with HMS Ulysses may very well be that MacLean reached too far....more

author: Slocum, Joshua
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One person's adventure is not necessarily another person's adventure.Sailing Alone Around the World is Joshua Slocum's self-narrated account of his soOne person's adventure is not necessarily another person's adventure.Sailing Alone Around the World is Joshua Slocum's self-narrated account of his solo voyage around the world in the 1890's. Everything about his voyage is worthy of being told. His voyage was made without radio, radar, GPS systems, or aircraft at the tail end of 19th Century. When Slocum sailed out over the horizon he was alone, known to no one, and to perish meant that he would simply disappear. But his narrative comes across as blasé and matter-of-fact.Slocum was too good at sailing. He avoided many hardships and mishaps due to his experience. The overall result is a narrative full of story but short on the types of insights that can only be gained through through adversity. The human abilities to learn, adapt, and overcome are the things that make an adventure. Overall, this is a wonderfully historical book, just not wonderfully adventurous....more

title: The Intruder
author: D'Annunzio, Gabriele
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When considered in the light of d'Annunzio's contemporaries, a light that's shed by the books that I've read by Henry James, Thomas Hardy, and Joseph When considered in the light of d'Annunzio's contemporaries, a light that's shed by the books that I've read by Henry James, Thomas Hardy, and Joseph Conrad, d'Annunzio outshines them all. His writing is somewhat typical of the times in that long paragraphs abound. However, rather than using these paragraphs to embellish various elements of the story, they instead served to hone in on the succinct emotions being experienced by the main character, Tullio Hermil. The result is a clear understanding of how Tullio thinks and feels during the telling of his tale. At any given moment, a multitude emotions are present and I could feel these complex emotions as his story progressed. The story is about love and marriage and I found the marriage of Tullio and Juliana to be as troubled as many marriages have ever been. However, there is sense that these two people come to understand what marriage is all about: forgiveness and commitment.But Tullio and Juliana are more than a typical married couple. Their station in life has instilled in them the attributes of selfishness, arrogance, and conceitedness. These attributes, when mixed with love's unique sort of reason, work to create a tragedy that is justified in the mind of Tullio; and understandable in the mind of the reader.It's a story that is honestly told with an apparent disregard to the social and religious conventions of the time. If I were told what this story was about beforehand, I'm not certain that I would want to read it, similar to the effect that Lolita sometimes has on that book's potential readers. However, this story's commitment to the emotional truth about people you would probably not want to know in life translates into a powerful reading experience.As for relevancy, this story readily transposes to the present day. While most of Tullio and Juliana's social constructs have been removed, there is still an abundance of selfishness, arrogance, and conceitedness in the world. So much so, that the worst parts of this tragedy are occasionally echoed in present-day headlines....more

title: Winnetou - The Apache Knight
author: May, Karl
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Write what you know." With those words I have probably quoted or paraphrased the advice of a countless number of writers. The reason for this advice "Write what you know." With those words I have probably quoted or paraphrased the advice of a countless number of writers. The reason for this advice is simple: the lie that is fiction must be perceived as a truth if a book is to stand the test of time. But then we have Winnetou - The Apache Knight. Karl Friedrich May was born in Germany in 1842 and lived to the age 70 without ever having stepped foot in the American West. Yet he chose to write about that unknown place in the absence of any first-hand experience; choosing to rely upon other means, such as travel memoirs, to know this mysterious land. By all accounts, he was a successful writer in his native country and the character Winnetou went on to appear in three subsequent novels.In spite of this success, however, May failed to capture the true nature of the American West. Absent from Winnetou are any meaningful descriptions of endless skies, jagged snow-capped peaks rising from the plains, and distant thunderstorms moving across distant horizons. Writers such as Zane Grey and Cormac McCarthy knew the power of such an unforgiving yet beautiful landscape and they used it to shape their characters, which in turn added substance to the content of their books.May's depictions of the American Indians are equally lacking in scope. The Apache and Kiowa Indians are represented as being simpletons that serve solely to provide the antagonism required of the plot. They are depicted as children when the wisdom of the "paleface" is being imparted to them; depicted as maniacal warriors when battles are fought; and depicted sadistic animals in the treatment of their prisoners. There is no complexity in these people probably due to May's ignorance of their culture.Essentially, May played a game wherein he took advantage of the relatively isolated state of the world in his time. The vast majority of May's readers had never stepped foot in America and they predominately communicated in their native German language. As a result, May's fans gained their knowledge of the American West through May's words and created a feedback loop that ensured his popularity for decades after his death.As WWII approached, it is not surprising that the German population, including Adolph Hitler, relied in part upon their beloved German writer to find insights into the nature of the American people. It's been documented that Hitler had 300,000 copies of Winnetou delivered to his soldiers. The Germans naturally reached for a source that was both readily available and readily enjoyed. It was this failure of the imagination, or rather this short-circuit of the imagination, that helped to create a false impression of Germany's future enemy. Winnetou predominately relies upon the action of its hero and his trusty sidekicks. As a result, their actions appear heroic and the actions of everyone else, presumably the average American, seem helpless, rash, and ineffectual. In the same way that May fails to capture any of the beauty of the American West and the complexity of the American Indians, he also fails to capture any of the humanity of the American people. He simply did not know these things, and today, I would hope that the world would know better....more

title: Aurora: CV-01        (The Frontiers Saga #1)
author: Brown, Ryk
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Take any 30-minute action sequence from a space-based video game, string the ensuing battle scenes together with a plot, create a group of characters Take any 30-minute action sequence from a space-based video game, string the ensuing battle scenes together with a plot, create a group of characters with military personalities to act out the sequence, and you have Aurora: CV-01. After the initial introductions, this book slides from one climatic battle scene to the next, to the next, to the next. So if you are into reading about the video games you just finished playing, this book is definitely for you.And yet? And yet, there was a spark of inquisitive thoughtfulness within those introductory chapters and hints of such thoughtfulness throughout the book. Brown raises the question as to whether or not humanity is capable of using technology that has been developed so fast that it seems like magic. Brown also raises the question as to whether or not war is always a necessity when faced with a seemingly aggressive opponent; and be speculates on the fine line that exists between rebels and terrorists. And throughout the book, people find themselves in positions where their decisions affect the lives of others, and each of these characters carry the burden of their decisions in different and unique ways.It's these sparks that have me wondering if a twelve-part series of books might just have more to it than the video game action that so saturated this first installment. Cautiously, I plan on seeing if things change in the next book....more

title: Koban        (Koban #1)
author: Bennett, Stephen W.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Koban is the first of a seven-book series that tells the tale of Humanity’s first contact with an alien species. The contact happens during a time wheKoban is the first of a seven-book series that tells the tale of Humanity’s first contact with an alien species. The contact happens during a time when faster-than-light travel has been discovered and humans have colonized nearby stars, all of which were uninhabited. The contact, far from being a universal ephimy of humanity’s existence, is hostile, brutal, and threatens to enslave humanity (or worse).It’s typical for sci-fi series of any length to sustain themselves through action, space battles, over-dramatized drama, and victories against unbeatable odds, and Koban has its fair share of these attributes. However, Koban also possess a contemplative approach to its story. Its plot rests on the strategy and actions of its characters. Will Humanity survive? The answer rests mostly in how clever humanity can be. It is through this means that Koban approaches one of the core purposes of science fiction.The disagreeable aspects of the book involved the characters. They all had their duties and responsibilities, and they all seemed to fade back into their storyline assignments rather than express individual personalities or feelings. There are no artists, or dreamers, or people passionate about anything other than staying alive. As a result, the death of a character is noted but not experienced.The story also had the potential to explore a unique situation within human society with its opening extinction of 90-plus percent of the male population. This set the table for a unique woman-dominated perspective, but Bennett fails to deliver on this theme. Men and their acts dominate the plot with the implication by Bennett, be it intentional or unintentional, is that men are the saviors of humanity. Overall, Koban is engaging with its logic and strategy, but lacking in its depiction of humanity and the humans that comprise it. It’s more or less just another Western set somewhere in space....more

title: Hard Rain Falling
author: Carpenter, Don
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I once spent five hours flying on board an aircraft watching consecutive episodes of Lockup Raw. I was hooked by the inmates and their stories. In epiI once spent five hours flying on board an aircraft watching consecutive episodes of Lockup Raw. I was hooked by the inmates and their stories. In episode after episode, prisoners, outcasts of society, were interviewed and each one told of their crimes (or of their innocence) in an honest straight forward manner. While on camera, they acted like they were talking to their next door neighbor. And yet, during all those hours of Lockup Raw, there was never an understanding of who these people were and the question of choice was never resolved. Why couldn't these criminals simply decide to not do the things they did?Hard Rain Falling provides some portion of understanding into who these people might be through its main character, Jack Levitt. While Jack Levitt was an outcast of society, it was not due to his poor decisions. Jack made the best decisions possible based on the content of his beliefs. It was also not due to his laziness. Jack worked as hard as he could to the physical and intellectual limits of his abilities. Nor was it due to a disinterest in learning. Jack had a hunger to learn and constantly sought to expand his understanding of the world. And it was not due to some sort of pure evilness of heart. Jack pursued love to the point of pain. If Jack Levitt was an outcast of society, then the only real reason for his position in life was the randomness associated with his creation.The strength of this book rests in the intricate development of its characters in the first two parts of the book. Carpenter succeeds in defining characters that are rational unto themselves, while at the same time appearing irrational when viewed from a societal perspective. Reasons for violence and crime abounded in the mind of Jack Levitt even though society would see things differently. This duplicity of perspective was engrossing and it makes Hard Rain Falling into a reading experience.The book's shortcomings rest in the third and final part. After being drawn into Carpenters world of complex characters, the third part of the book seems light and rushed. Rather than achieving a sense of duplicity that was previously relished, the characters in the third part of the book seemed, at times, contradictory. Hard Rain Falling is still a great book, but another hundred pages devoted to the last part of the book would have made it unique....more

review: Solaris speaks to our inherent desire to explore. Humans have been explorers for a very long time. It's a trait that has been encoded into us by thoseSolaris speaks to our inherent desire to explore. Humans have been explorers for a very long time. It's a trait that has been encoded into us by those that first left the warmth and safety of Africa to find better lands on which to survive. It's a trait that has served us well during our existence.Upon its discovery, the planet Solaris offered humans the ultimate destination for exploration. If its mysteries could be decoded and understood then the corresponding joy of discovery would be unparalleled. An entire branch of science is dedicated to this unique world and in the beginning, expeditions of vast proportions were sent to study this world with its strange ocean and its uniquely stable orbit around binary stars.But what happens when our explorations go unanswered and discovery is replaced with an endless supply of meaningless phenomenon? We may one day venture out into the galaxy only to find that all of the countless worlds out there are as devoid of intelligent life as suggested by all the data we have gathered to-date.Exploration without discovery is the main point of Solaris. The book depicts that less joyous aspect of life where the search for discovery constantly goes unanswered; or where a discovery of an answer is not possible from the very start. Hope, faith, and love are magical things, but sometimes that is all that they are....more

title: Proxima
author: Baxter, Stephen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I typically refrain from writing long s but Proxima had so much to like in parallel with a constant undertow of disappointment that I felt the nI typically refrain from writing long s but Proxima had so much to like in parallel with a constant undertow of disappointment that I felt the need to document both the good and the bad. My general feeling of the book is that Baxter made a remarkable attempt at writing an outstanding science fiction novel. So here are the details.The good...With the science fiction genre is consumed by space operas and their gallivanting, phaser-blasting starship captains, it’s rare to find a story that is contemplative in its content. Proxima is not about shooting wars in space, alien invasions, or mystical worlds. Rather, it’s a story that has one foot in presently reality while taking a step towards what we might become in the future; about 200 years into the future.The story is careful in its science to respect fundamental constructs that are known to be true. The speed of light, the effects of gravity, and our need for a habitable environment outside of the safety of our pale blue dot are all respected. There are no shortcuts when it comes to these hard and fast constraints.Then there are the scientific extrapolations. They allow the reader to see possible futures related to current issues that are destined to grow in importance as time proceeds. Baxter provides illustrative outcomes to the possible effects of global warming, artificial intelligence, and the presence of Earth-like exoplanets. His extrapolations are thoughtful, and show a genuine respect for science and engineering. And beyond those things that are possible lie the purely fictional elements, where the unknown is brought into existence. These elements of the story serve to highlight our potential (or lack thereof). With the discovery of an unimaginable power source that is closely guarded by half of humanity, the book asks if such a discovery will bring us together as a species or will the weakest parts of ourselves further separate us into factions eager for a violent solution.And now the bad...First, Baxter advances two timelines that fluctuate in time separation throughout the book. Some chapters are opened with the year, which helps, but others are silent with Baxter assuming that the date is understood. From my own lack of experience in dealing with relativistic time shifts, more attention to timekeeping by Baxter would have helped to keep me oriented to his story.The next disappointment relates to the characters. They all tend to be interchangeable regardless of their background. Their names serve as their primary distinguishing characteristic. They all exhibit a stoic fatalism with some entertaining sarcasm being expressed from time-to-time, but nothing deeper. This seems to be a recurring shortcoming of the science fiction genre. It’s as if writers that excel in imagining the future have an inability to capture the uniqueness of a human individual.And finally, the plot serves only Baxter's vision of the story. He does not pause for answers to questions that his readers are likely to have along the way. Events transpire that are not explained. Obvious inconsistencies in his imagined technology are not addressed. And threats that would seem easy to neutralize in a technologically advanced world are allowed to proceed as if we were helpless to stop them. Baxter largely ignores (or fails to imagine) the thoughts of his readers who will certainly be living along side Baxter throughout his story....more

title: Split Images
author: Leonard, Elmore
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are writers that use their characters to explore the nature of humanity. They dissect their character's thoughts and actions in order to get to There are writers that use their characters to explore the nature of humanity. They dissect their character's thoughts and actions in order to get to the The Heart of the Matter. They work for small bits of truth in a sea of reality and they often succeed, if they are good.But humans do not fall open to scrutiny so easily. Often in life, the person in front of you simply acts without any hint as to the reasons why. There is no narrator speaking from above and their complexity is protected by their skin, their eyes, and the depths of their mind. For what we see, they simply act and it is only after the fact that we can contemplate their actions. But their actions are human because that is what we all are.This is Leonard's approach to Split Images. His characters are complete in their complexity. Their actions are beholden to no explanation other than some mysterious thought process that remains their own. Leonard takes a wedge out the world, puts it between the front and back covers, and lets his readers see life play out on every page. It takes a subtle hand to create such a reality in words, but Leonard seems to know that life is seldom more than the sum total of the actions of the people living it....more

review: I found Jane Eyre to be a classic English literary novel in every preconceived way. Within its pages were images of English landscapes, country mansioI found Jane Eyre to be a classic English literary novel in every preconceived way. Within its pages were images of English landscapes, country mansions, starched white collars and satin dresses, and a story that sprawls slowly (oh, so very slowly) from place to place, from start to end. In keeping with the times of its creation, it would be easy to picture Brontë showing this work to her peers in much the same way the ladies of the novel took pride in their own artistic accomplishments. It's a delicate and intricate book, whose words prove that the English language can be a beautiful thing.The book's survival for over 150 years, however, cannot be due to language alone and to be sure, there are a number of themes throughout this book that give it its present-day relevancy. Religious enthusiasts will find an abundance of moral lessons as well as multiple scenes of self-deprivation made in the name of God. It's also remarkable how independent Jane Eyre becomes during an era when men and their wealth controlled much of the world. Jane Eyre also serves as a time capsule in that the book brings light to the mannerisms and living conditions of Brontë's era. Finally, the book challenges its readers to take note of the quality of the beliefs that guide their actions. Are theses beliefs founded in reality, or are they founded in faith alone? 150 years ago, faith and reality were practically one in the same, and since that time, not much has changed.Yes, Jane Eyre is all that, which is just a bit too much....more

title: The Martian
author: Weir, Andy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It would have been impossible for me to not have liked this book. Yes, it’s been hyped and made into a movie and a lot of people have made a lot of moIt would have been impossible for me to not have liked this book. Yes, it’s been hyped and made into a movie and a lot of people have made a lot of money. But after reading The Martian, I have come to the conclusion that all of that is organic to the writing and to the story.First, there is nerdom. Real science abounds on every page. Not that science-fiction stuff that fades in and out of reality, but true, present-day science, based in technology that spans all areas of practical application. There is rocket science (of course), but the fields of electrical, civil, mechanical, agricultural science and engineering are extensively included in the story. I understand that Weir incorporated updates and corrections that he received from scientists and engineers while this book was being posted on-line, in installments, prior to its commercial publication. This commitment to reality translates as a commitment to truth, which always makes for a great book.Then there is the humor. Deep satirical humor that is fueled by consequences and leads full circle to genuine joy or pain in the heart of the reader. This book is deadly serious but you will find yourself smiling throughout the story. The dry and satirical humor adds a finishing touch to most scenes and it elicits a deeper emotional response to the situations that arise.Minor issues? Yes, the characters could be stronger, more defined. Humans are far more complex than they appear to be. We are never as mission-focused as those depicted in the story. And finally, there is space, where losing a roll of the dice just once typically ends the game. There is a vague feeling that builds throughout the novel that our stranded astronaut is invincible in the face of repeated adversity. But feel free to disregard this last paragraph and tell me to lighten up. The Martian is an fun reading experience, especially for the nerds of this world....more

title: The Discovery of Freedom: Man's Struggle Against Authority
author: Lane, Rose Wilder
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The idea put forward by Rose Wilder Lane has merit. I think most people would agree that limited government interference in one's life leads to an incThe idea put forward by Rose Wilder Lane has merit. I think most people would agree that limited government interference in one's life leads to an increased ability to survive and thrive in this world. It's and idea that acknowledges that government cannot understand any one person's individual needs so laws and regulations that try to shape the behaviors and actions of an individual are generally a bad thing. Had Lane simply presented this idea, its successes and its failures, there would have probably been widespread acceptance of her book.But Lane passionately and desperately tries to prove this idea in the extreme, which is something that cannot be proven. Present this idea to a dozen people and a spectrum of replies will be received in return. Complicate the presentation with a specific example and those replies will change. There is no correct opinion beyond the mind of any individual and the specific case being considered.In spite of this reality, Lane presses ahead with her efforts and departs from reason. First, she defines all individuals that disagree with her as having a single spiritual flaw: a deep seeded religious faith in their respective Old World Governments (and the word Government is purposely capitalized throughout the book as an allusion to God). After profiling all those in opposition to her as religious devotees, her writing focuses on affecting their enlightenment through education.Lane's educational curriculum is comprised of arguments consisting of half-truths, over-simplifications, and mistruths to support her points. She dwells extensively on examples where she presents elements that are supportive to her assertions while completely ignoring relevant elements to the contrary. American history, European history, and the history of the Middle-East are all subjects that are cherry-picked and shaped by Lane.The Discovery of Freedom was published in 1943 and leaders of the time used similar methods to educate their citizens with their own versions of the truth. Roosevelt used fireside chats, Hitler used his grand assemblies, and Churchill used his oratory skills. Lane's methods are in keeping with the times. The book rings of classic propaganda served up for acceptance as the truth as long as no questions are asked.This propagandistic style creates significant problems for the book. While Lane wants people to abandon their presumed religious beliefs in their Government, it becomes apparent that she is perfectly willing to accept a faith-based conversion to her point of view and to have the newly converted pre-programmed with her spoon-fed Truths. This approach implies Lane's lack of trust in those that would be converted and by extension, a lack of trust, by Lane, in her own idea. After all, an idea that is true should be able to withstand evidence to the contrary.As a consequence, The Discovery of Freedom reads with a continuous undertone of skepticism and Lane's credibility as an educator continuously evaporates along the way. There are passages that contradict earlier discussions. For instance, Lane asserts that individual voting for the president of the United States and our senators is a dangerous thing; that US citizens should have a religious faith in the Electoral College delegates and senators that would be appointed by State governments if it were not for the Seventeenth Amendment. The universal flaw used by Lane against her opponents finally becomes a quality that should be embraced by true believers in the original US Constitution and the government it formed. The irony runs deep. The best part of this version of The Discovery of Freedom is the foreword. I have to give its writer, Windy McElroy, and the publisher credit for not editing out Lane's own opinions regarding The Discovery of Freedom. During Lane's lifetime, only the initial run of 1,000 copies was published and she would not allow a second printing. In her words, Lane said, "It's a very bad book. I ought to know. I wrote it." And I happen to agree....more

title: Dark Digital Sky        (Dark Pantheon Series Book 1)
author: Allison, Carac*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My preference in books could be described as residing in the general area of literary realism. Therefore, for any given book, the closer the setting, My preference in books could be described as residing in the general area of literary realism. Therefore, for any given book, the closer the setting, characters, and plot are to what I perceive to be real, the better the chances are that I will enjoy that book.Dark Digital Sky comes closest to realism with its main character, Chalk. While the book is a hard-boiled detective story, a modern take on the classic film noir style, it's the perfect medium for Chalk. He's a manifestation of the undercurrent of society. He has been exposed to failures and disillusionments. His life-experiences have transformed him into a cynical realist who easily dismisses the illusion of hope for a reality that simply happens without consideration for anyone. I believed in Chalk and believed in his beliefs.Dark Digital Sky's plot, however, undermines this realism. While Chalk is true-to-life, the life that surrounds him is not. We simply do not see the events that transpire in Dark Digital Sky happen. Even extrapolations of reality fall short of these events. Today's surveillance grid, as understood through contemporary reports on the NSA, PRISM, and Snowden, would likely stop a rogue militia group before reaching the critical mass needed to act as depicted in this book. Chalk's own technological expertise alludes to these counter-terrorism capabilities but the government is shown to be irrelevant and inept. As a result of this disconnect, Chalk finds himself fighting against a whirlwind of fantasy (and sighs).As a first novel, I think Dark Digital Sky's is an exceptional accomplishment on the part of Alison. Chalk captured my attention and speaks to the talent that Alison has in creating interesting and believable characters. This first novel has me looking forward to his next....more

title: Robbery under Arms; a story of life and adventure in the bush and in the Australian goldfields
author: Boldrewood, Rolf
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My impression of Robbery Under Arms is one of appreciation that such a book exists. Boldrewood (or Browne, as that was his actual name) captures the sMy impression of Robbery Under Arms is one of appreciation that such a book exists. Boldrewood (or Browne, as that was his actual name) captures the setting and spirit of colonial Australia during the middle of the 19th Century, as it happened. The book captures the feeling of that remote colony and his writing captures the dialect of a people that worked apart from the Old World to make Australia their home. From there, there is a feeling of kinship that grows from the similarities that exist between the history of the American West and those of this then-distant land. This book is filled with cattle, ranchers, horses, towns, cowboys, ranges and mountains. Had the story been set in Oklahoma the spirit these things would have changed very little. But while the actions that drive this book could have been written by Elmore Leonard or Zane Grey, they weren't. This book, through-and-through, is uniquely Australian.The central theme gives rise to considerations of justice. Does the doling out of punishment that simply fits the crime, regardless of circumstances, truly balance the scales held in the hand of justice? Or are the scales held aloft as a distraction for that other item she holds in her other hand? Society controls punishment and those outside of society have little say in it's application. Thus, mercy is more of a man-made miracle with respect to just punishment and the finger of society forever rests upon the scales.The tone of the book is truly sincere. It's no spoiler to say that the story is told from the first-person perspective of a condemned man and from his narrative the reader grows to understand this man's path towards his fate. The narration is matter-of-fact and deliberately avoids gimmicks such as mystery, suspense, and over-played action. This approach allows the reader to focus on the acts and circumstances of the characters and to better understand the story of the condemned....more

title: The Good Shepherd
author: Forester, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a young recruit in the US Navy, one of the more important doctrines drilled into my mind was that authority could be delegated, but responsibility As a young recruit in the US Navy, one of the more important doctrines drilled into my mind was that authority could be delegated, but responsibility never departs from the person in command. Should you find yourself in command of a bathroom cleaning crew or a capital warship, everything that happens under your command is your responsibility. And when the weight of that absolute responsibility is combined with the emotions associated with duty and honor, the result is a person that is structured to endure the extremes of human existence for a worthwhile cause.The strength of The Good Shepherd is that it highlights this type of person in terms of Commander George Krause. Krause is an average naval officer that by chance finds himself in command of an under-strength group of destroyers tasked with the protection of a transatlantic convey from U-boat attacks. The story moves Krause through the spectrum of human endurance and demonstrates how his own combination of absolute responsibility, duty, and honor work under impossible conditions.Beyond Krause's demonstration of good naval conduct, however, The Good Shepherd reads as a superficial story. The crew appear as a rotation of ranked and named individuals that have no personal characteristics, a past, or a future. Their actions either please or displease Krause and after a while they become a jumble of extras that are confusingly ignored. The story as well, becomes tedious. There is only one way for a destroyer to hunt a submerged submarine, which is to attempt to chase it down. This process of hide-n-seek is continuously repeated throughout the book. The sub hunts become a jumble of rudder commands, course headings, and reports all of which are acknowledged by the tried and true naval phrase, “very well.” The book also assumes a fair amount of knowledge of the naval environment which, if not present in the reader, could further serve to isolate the story.There is not much here to enjoy beyond the celebration of duty that is exemplified by the captain and I found that reading The Good Shepherd required a bit of Krause's own ability to endure in order to make it to the end. But then again, this may have been the point.Note: C. S. Forester spent time on board the destroyer, USS Abner Read (DD-526) in June 1943. My grandfather, Edwin Villines, was a machinist mate on board at the time. The Abner Read, with my grandfather, would eventually be struck by a mine in August 1943 during the Aleutian Island campaign and ultimately sunk by a kamikaze strike on November 1, 1944 while in Leyte Gulf, Philippine Islands. My grandfather managed to abandon ship and was rescued by the USS Claxton (DD-571)....more

review: Alistair Reynolds is a craftsman. The galaxy he creates in Revelation Space strikes at the heart of what I would realistically imagine our future to bAlistair Reynolds is a craftsman. The galaxy he creates in Revelation Space strikes at the heart of what I would realistically imagine our future to be as we head out into the stars. Humans are still imperfect, we are still selfish, and our love for the integration of technology into our lives is taken not to its conclusion, but rather to a realistic step along the way. He weaves in scientific facts that are explained to the point of consistency with his story such as his respect for the vast distances between the stars and the effects of time when traveling close to, but not faster than the speed of light. Additionally, Reynolds creates a humanity that is in the process of fracturing into different cultures due to the colonization of new worlds that are extremely far apart. This part of Revelation Space was worth the read: 5 stars for a thought-provoking setting.A great book, however, is more than its setting. Outside of his galaxy, Reynolds struggled with the creation of realistic characters. While human, the characters fail to display any convincing human emotions or provide human reasons for their actions. Reynolds 'tells' of his character's actions rather than 'showing' them. As a result, tales of love are told with mechanical accuracy, freedoms are denied without frustration or anguish, and anger is expressed through the occasional expletive. The characters are simply a means to justify the existence of his version of the galaxy.The plot suffers as well mostly from a lack of cohesion caused by its gratuitous use of forced suspense. While the book consists of 39 chapters, each chapter contains two or three shifts between storylines in order to make the reader wait for that next tidbit of information no matter how minor. The plot also suffers from scenes of pointless action. Things are blown up, shot at, or destroyed with exotic weapons, which provides Reynolds the chance to lecture his readers on their sci-fi composition and function. These two gimmicks, suspense and action, attempt to hold the reader to the book. However, after 300 pages the novel becomes tiresome and it was somewhat of a relief to have finally reached the last page....more

title: Galaxies Like Grains of Sand
author: Aldiss, Brian W.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Galaxies Like Grains of Sand  is a solid work of science fiction. It accomplishes what so many books in the genre surprisingly fail to do, which is toGalaxies Like Grains of Sand  is a solid work of science fiction. It accomplishes what so many books in the genre surprisingly fail to do, which is to raise questions about our collective future based upon our past and present conditions. For those that want to consider far reaching ideas about our long-term societal and human evolutionary paths, Galaxies Like Grains of Sand  has no shortage of such ideas.My issues with Galaxies stem from its structure. It attempts to be one complete text that presents fragments of Earth's history through countless millennia into the future. To accomplish this structure, the book is comprised of several short stories that are tied together with brief prefaces that focus on the book's historical theme.Aldiss' approach fragments the characters and the setting of each story while the central them of Earth's history is carried through to the end. Consequently, the characters and settings of each story serve Aldiss' purpose, but they fail to elicit any lasting sympathy. The characters simply vanish as the next fragment begins.The end result feels more like a recital of Aldiss' version of Revelation, and the human implications associated with Aldiss' visions are left to a sort of faith in him as the all-knowing writer. In the absence of sympathy, there is no way to feel a sense of truth in Aldiss' words.I think science fiction is capable of a literary story; complete with characters that communicate the nature of their existence, a setting that extrapolates realistic speculations on science, and a plot that strikes close to a human understanding of life. But so far, such a book has been elusive....more

author: Arseneault, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: AMP Messenger could have taken place anywhere here on earth as opposed to some distant point in space and time. The science fiction setting was only cAMP Messenger could have taken place anywhere here on earth as opposed to some distant point in space and time. The science fiction setting was only central to the writer's need to use imaginary nouns with techno-babble names. Otherwise, substitute rival gangs/factions/countries for rival alien species and the plot would not need to be changed. Whether past, present, or future: swords, guns, and blasters are all one in the same. Furthermore, the characters are so thin that re-writing their surroundings to match any point in time would be an easy thing to do.And therein lies the dissatisfaction with this book. Since fiction should have a purpose beyond having fun with alien races and scripting battle scenes in space. In this instance, we have humanity isolated to a point where our true human nature, devoid of history, could have been explored. Are we inherently cruel and selfish, is a society based on reason obtainable, does history repeat itself even in the absence of history? With AMP Messenger, simply look around you today and that is the society of Arseneault's future. Maybe that simple present-day observation answers those questions, but if so, Arseneault missed an opportunity to explain why he thinks our future will remain unchanged from our present, or more likely, he had no intention of doing anything other than exactly what he did. Either way, there is nothing to learn from this book....more

review: The House of Mirth contrasts opposite poles of the moral compass. On one side, there’s the main character, Lily Bart, and her high moral bearing. LilyThe House of Mirth contrasts opposite poles of the moral compass. On one side, there’s the main character, Lily Bart, and her high moral bearing. Lily is contrasted by the gluttons of society: those created from the slop of excessive wealth. While Lily initially views the gluttons with envy, she gradually learns that their world is one that is set apart. It a world comprised of its own rules that allow for morals to be twisted to fit rationalized acts, no matter how immoral those acts are. The struggle that ensues between Lily and the gluttons highlights the ineffective power that is imparted to those with high moral standards. When doing the right thing is pitted against those who are threatened with the loss of wealth, Lily finds that good moral intentions are no match against immoral acts that are supported by power and wealth. Thus, the need for morals as an absolute construct in one’s life is questioned throughout the story.The negative aspect of the story is that the human characters are a bit distorted to fit into their respective camps. In spite of a fundamental human desire for justice, it was convenient that all of the gluttons, even the couple that cared for Lily, were all of one mind in their desire to remove her from their company. Similarly, Lily Bart could have obtained vindication but decided that such an act of justice was in conflict with her moral convictions. I think that if this were a true story, rather than one of scripted fiction, the events depicted in The House of Mirth would have turned out differently....more

title: Rebecca
author: du Maurier, Daphne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Being victimized is an ever-present risk in life. In addition to the bad things that happen, there are a countless number of disappointments, twists oBeing victimized is an ever-present risk in life. In addition to the bad things that happen, there are a countless number of disappointments, twists of fate, and accidents that happen regularly. Every time one of these things occurs, we feel a sense of injustice and from there we can fall into a state of self-pity: "why me?" ... Or, we can move on without ever having addressed the problem. We then exist in a state of denial about your own victimization, which gives rise to other deep-seeded issues as life goes on.Rebecca reads like a tribute to victimhood. The main character tells her story in the first person and every event is something that weighs heavily on her poor poor soul. She seems to constantly be operating in a state of self-despair. I'm feeling rather faint just thinking about it. Maxim, on the other hand, fails to confront his problems and becomes so self-absorbed through most of the book that he jeopardizes the tings he holds most dear in his life. There is a third option to victimization, however. Rather than feeling that sympathy is due or trying to deny that anything bad ever happened, one can examine the events that transpired, reason with them, and try to understand them. It is through this approach that lessons can be learned, causes can be identified, and forgiveness can be found (especially for yourself). It is through this approach to tragedy that tragic events can be put behind you, catalogued as simply the way life is. It is this third option that is frustratingly lacking in Rebecca.On the positive side, I enjoyed the layout of the mystery, which is one of the main drivers of the plot. My usual problem with mysteries is their typical approach where the writer simply keeps an obvious bit of information off the page. In Rebecca, du Maurier subtly drops obvious elements of the future plot along the way. In stead of "Ha! I got you!" the experience is more along the lines of "Why didn't you see this coming?" and I did, once or twice....more

title: The Pilot: A Tale of the Sea
author: Cooper, James Fenimore
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In reading historical fiction novels, I’ve noticed that the story is always affected by the placement in time of two lenses. The first lens is fixed aIn reading historical fiction novels, I’ve noticed that the story is always affected by the placement in time of two lenses. The first lens is fixed at the time of the writer. Its location is measured by the time that has elapsed from the historical events depicted in the novel. As history fades into the past, the facts that comprise it become obscured and they degrade. Society also changes with time, which can change the writer’s interpretation of history.The Second lens is set in the time-frame of the reader. If a great distance in time exists between the writing and reading of a historical fiction novel, then the two states of society can become at odds with one another and the story can degrade into nonsense or fantasy. With The Pilot, the lenses are optimally spaced. The fifty years that separated the Revolutionary War and Cooper’s words give this novel a wonderful focus. The mannerisms and behaviors of the characters are nicely preserved. And Cooper is close enough to the war to let us see that it was in truth a British Civil War and that the 'South,' in the eyes of the British, actually won this internal struggle.As for the placement of the second lens, that of the reader, a little less patriotism in our stories about the Revolutionary War is exactly what we need in our present-day society. I thought it was remarkable that the attitudes of both sides were expressed so evenhandedly by Cooper, an American writer. It was actually refreshing in terms of today’s political climate, where simply hugging the flag is enough to gain a surprising amount of popular approval.The story itself twists and turns quite often but each curve comes in its own time. This leads to a tale that is easy to follow, which is a good thing given that the English language from two hundred years ago can be difficult to follow.The characters are likable and the distance in time between then and now serves to illuminate a couple timeless aspects of life. One is the supportive nature of life-experience that transcends artificial conditions such as rank and social structure. And another element is that people may see themselves as great, but how we see ourselves has very little bearing on who we actually are....more
